summary: Fresh out of college, five friends (Nadine Crocker, Matthew Daddario, Samuel Davis) face the horrors of a flesh-eating virus while staying at a remote cabin.

reviews.content: It was not scary and all around sucked!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Absolutely awful. Low budget. Diabolical acting.

Even though it will not beat the originals, it's definitely a movie worth watching if you're a fan of the series. It has its moments where it leaves you yawning, but it has some vivid plot twists too. But like most new movies added into a series, it has its disappointments.
I wish I could rate this less than half a star! Absolutely horrendous acting, how are movies this bad even released haha director needs a new job I think

If I could give this ZERO stars, I would (RT has changed over the years). None of the Cabin Fever movies were any good, not even the first one (I don't care how "better" it is compared to this), but this movie...I can't think if it's worse or even just as bad as the second one (the one with the prom/dance).

It's a note-by-note remake of the first one, which means everything you see in the first film is present here, with little to no changes (the only real changes are the deputy's change of sex, and the "iconic" pancakes scene). It tried to be more gory and horror, like The Evil Dead Remake, but it failed on that part remarkably.

Don't waste your time. They should've just given Patient Zero a sequel instead.

While being an alright remake it lacks everything the original had- humour and lots of gore. Also YOU CAN'T REPLACE WINSTON! I'm sure this change was made as Giuseppe went dark unfortunately but still, leave him out. It is also way way to serious for a cabin fever film.
No need for a quarantine -- enthusiasm for this inert remake is not contagious.

Holy shit.  By far one of the WORST remakes I've ever seen. I understand it's not a reboot, it's a remake. But fuck dude, you don't film each scene the exact same scene as the original but with shitty acting and absolute no humor at all. I'm just... I hate this. Only reason it got the 1 star treatment and not a .5 is because some of that musical score was really hair raising.... until the characters started talking again
Just a bunch of unnecessary gore and a poor storyline and script with bad acting...not much to enjoy here!
This movie proves that with a budget of $100, some ham and ketchup, an Air bnb and an iPhone - anything is possible. Props to the actors for working with what they were given.
I went in not knowing it was a remake and was treated to a self-serious horror film that would work better as a black comedy.
It really does not live up to the original. It should have never been done. The original film is incredibly hilarious in a very dark, yet real way. This film did not capture that same atmosphere.
I liked how it was filmed, and the music that went with it.
I thought it wasn't too bad, with the exception of me yelling at my tv because of the stupidity of the characters

Everything is same like Original ,This Location look Great ,Less Creepy Scene Than Original 
ps. I Can't Enjoy with This Because i seen Original i Know What will Happen But This 3.5 Star Meaning i Recomend This If You "Never" Watch Original
I had no idea it was a remake but it was pretty mediocre. It seemed just another forgettable horror movie. It wasn't funny either.

This movie is abysmal. I remember watching it with a group of my friends because it was Halloween (almost) and we wanted to get scared. Well... we were not. After about 2 minutes into the movie, I grabbed the remote, paused it, and said, "Okay what?" The cinematography was good, and the effects were stunning. Its clear that all the budget went there. Instead of being scared and horrified at the boy with the bunny mask biting one of the main characters, we literally had to pause it as I almost fell out of my bed...from laughter. The infamous try again scene succeed in being gross, but it was not scary. Overall this movie is definitely a watch if you have a large group of friends with you. 

-wyane

I loved the 2002 version of this movie and decided to take a stab at the remake, since nothing was on and I didnt realize they made a new one. I soon realized there is a reason that I wasn't made aware. This movie is pretty much a shot for shot remake, except for a bit more gore, horrendous line delivery, and writing, and characters with enough personality to fill a teaspoon. Even with remakes of beloved originals, I try and find one positive thing about them. Honestly, there was none. Except the makeup department. I will give credit where credit is due and say that they make the infected look truely grotesque. 

But yeah. this movie was 99 minutes of my life that I will never see again and watching it made me almost feel like I was in Karen's shoes.....painful and begging someone to kill me.
1/5.  A completely unnecessary remake, this movie is basically the exact same as the original and adds nothing new to the series.
the original was good, this is a shallow and lack luster remake, and totally necessary to boot

A shot for shot schlockfest. The original Cabin Fever has more than enough detractors, understandably so. The combination of hyper campy explotation and spatterfest gore makes for an uncomfortably hour and a half (that's why I adore it) - in fact, as a unapologetic Eli Roth fanboy I find it hard to understand why Roth not only signed off on this unnecessary remake but also co-produced. The charm and camp of the original has been replaced by...well...I guess you could say it's gorier? There, half a start for a bit more blood. Ultimately this is a lifeless, irritatingly pointless excercise.
I watched the remake of Cabin Fever (Netflix) last night and it was hilariously awful. OMG the plotholes, the useless characters, and even a shot where you see a crew member by accident. So bad.

This remake is without doubt one of the worst films I've ever had the displeasure of enduring. Considering the original holds up well and didn't even need remaking, this seems like a waste of everyone's time and money.
Absolutely shocking. Terrible acting, terrible directing, terrible plot. Just completely dreadful.
Horribly gory, demented and gross.
Nothing in this movie even tries to make sense.

Don't be fooled by the two-star review. This movie was hilarious and I recommend watching it. I'm giving it two stars because it was super cheesy and had 39.5 plot holes, but as for how much I enjoyed it--it's worth it.
Every single cents spent on this film is wasted. Everyone involved in this film should consider this an end of their career.
It’s one of those movies that try to be so bad it’s good. But it’s just bad.

I (regrettably?) have not seen the original and therefore I can't judge the movie relative to that but I can judge the movie relative to what's objectively good and this Cabin Fever remake doesn't have a shred of anything close to that label.
A modern twist on the Eli Roth classic. Not as good, but it’s pretty much the same plot. If you love horror movies it’s still a decent watch, if you’re not I’d keep moving along.

You know it's a bad movie when you: root for the bad guys (from the store); don't like any of the characters; hate yourself for even watching it; want the characters to just die already. Felt all of those with this movie. Wish I could give it 0 stars. Do not watch if you want to leave with your sanity intact.

This was quite possibly the most boring remake I've ever seen. In fact, it might be the worst "horror" movie I've ever seen. No real tension whatsoever. This movie was a waste of time money grab if I've ever seen one.  0/10 would recommend

At the point of this movie's release, 14 years had passed between the original movie and its remake.  I think that's just way too short of a time to wait for a remake, to be perfectly honest.  I remember talking, in my Mad Money review, about how, while there are still remakes left and right in Hollywood, they aren't as bad or as prevalent now as they were in the past.  And then, a couple of days after that movie, I end up watching this.  Quite possibly the most unnecessary horror remake in quite some time.  If the idea was to bring the Cabin Fever story to a new generation of horror fans, given that, again, at that point, almost half a decade had passed between movies, then why not just do a re-release of the original.  Which, I'm assuming, has a big cult following and it can be a merging of two different generations of horror fans, those who watched the movie when it first came out (I was a part of that, I was 14 when the original came out) and those who want to experience it for themselves for the first time because they may have been too young to watch it.  That would actually be a pretty cool idea.  Honestly, as much as I've enjoyed some Eli Roth movies, as far as I remember, I wasn't that big of a fan of the original Cabin Fever.  I only watched it the one time in the theaters and I would welcome a re-watch.  The pointof the matter is that this really is an absolutely unnecessary update of the original movie and, quite frankly, it's worse than the original.  I'm honestly surprised that, out of 28 reviews on RottenTomatoes, there was not a single positive one.  Not a one.  No one had anything positive to say about this movie.  I'll be honest, the only other Cabin Fever movie I watched (there's two more, if you weren't aware), was Patient Zero.  I wouldn't go out of my way to say that that was a good movie, but I felt that it had tremendous practical special and make-up effects.  It was really impressive for what, essentially, was a low-budget direct-to-video affair.  Shame they were servicing a movie that was, largely, not very good.  And, if there was only one expectation I came into with this movie, was for it to have quality blood and gore and, honestly, the movie definitely delivered on that.  I don't think the practical effects are ever as gruesome as those in Patient Zero and it feels like to give the appearance that this was a better film than it actually was, but it's still really damn strong.  Watching the flesh-eating virus as it takes effect over our characters is a joy to watch.  The problem, of course, is everything else.  Conceptually, the movie plays out very much like Carpenter's The Thing.  I realize that that's probably the first, and only time, anyone will ever compare this to one of the classics.  What I mean is that the idea of paranoia as a result of the fact that you don't know who has the virus is very similar to The Thing, where this...monster is able to mimic human beings perfectly.  The characters in The Thing don't know who the monster is and that creates mistrust in a very claustrophobic setting, which certainly didn't help matters.  The movie is going for something along those same lines and, well, it just doesn't work.  Problem is just the fact that you never, at any point in time, care about any of these characters.  They are the stereotypical teens going out to a cabin in the forest/woods you've seen time and time again.  And, really, after Cabin in the Woods, you can't just offer this concept up without at least attempting to subvert some of the tropes associated with this set-up, but they don't.  They're very content to play into those tired genre cliches.  The fact of the matter is that the characters in this movie are just really poorly written and quite unlikable.  Bert is an absolutely insufferable character, to the point where his presence actively detracts from the experience.  A lot of the character work just makes no sense.  For example, Bert, when it's apparent that Paul and Karen are becoming an item, starts acting like such a fucking dick.  He berates Paul because he likes Karen because she nice to him and she likes him because she can control him.  And it's like, well, fuck, that escalated quickly.  It came from out of nowhere and was nonsensical because Karen has never, at any point, displayed signs of trying to control Paul.  So it makes Bert's rant absurd, as if they were trying to give me more of a reason to hate him.  Apparently just being himself wasn't enough.  And then there's the whole thing with the infected guy coming up to the cabin and everything that happened and how the characters try to act as if it was an accident, when they were clearly responsible for everything that happened.  This man was looking for help, they denied him that help and so he tried to steal their car.  That's fair enough to me.  So for them to try and play it off like it was self-defense was fucking bullshit, you guys are the real villains here, the virus is the real hero.  Not all heroes wear capes, much less if that hero is a fucking flesh-eating virus.  The movie fails miserably at creating any sort of tension that would lead to the paranoia that comes as a result of the characters not knowing who has the virus and to what extent.  There's a jarring shift where Jeff, who was...tolerable at best, turns into a total rich boy preppy asshole.  It happens out of nowhere, the characters are just arguing and he comes out acting like a total asshole.  I don't know much about cacti, but I know a prick when I see one.  And the sad thing is that the movie relies so much on this when it's just not that good.  It's not interesting and, most of all, it's not entertaining.  The scripting leaves a lot to be desired.  If you want this atmosphere of constant paranoia to work, where nobody knows who they can trust, it works best if you actually have characters that you can somewhat invest in.  Not saying that they have to be super likable, but just characters that you feel can exist within the context of this universe.  Again, they don't have to be likable, you just have to believe in them within the context of the universe.  I didn't believe in any of them here.  They're just poorly written assholes.  Another issue I had is that the score, while good, feels way too intrusive in some scenes and over-the-top for this type of movie.  Going back to the characters being assholes, it's as if the movie realized this because the third act or so, when the horror really cranks up, it's like an entirely different movie.  By this point I feel that it was too late to change anything, but the horror is decent and tense enough.  There is one incredibly stupid moment.  I'm gonna try to avoid spoiling anything, but there comes a point when Paul has to mercy kill one of his friends.  He drives a a shovel into this person's mouth, separating the jaw from the rest of the face.  Somehow, though, this person survives and is actually able to yell at Paul to kill him/her.  Paul, instead of putting a friend out of his/her misery quickly, proceeds to throw gas all over them and set them on fire.  Now, if you were following the movie, throwing gas over these people infected with the virus really fucking burns them.  So Paul, the fucking dumbass, chooses to "mercy kill" one of his friends in THE MOST PAINFUL WAY POSSIBLE.  I imagine being burnt alive is the worst way to die even without a flesh eating virus consuming me from the inside out, so can you imagine the pain this person had to have felt.  And this moment is played poignantly, like it's supposed to be fucking sad.  Paul is crying outside in the shed as he watches the smoke come out from it.  This was just really fucking stupid.  How was this a good idea in anyone's mind???  Decent third act aside, this movie is just bad when you get right down to it.  I'm giving it two stars because of the third act and the practical effects.  Other than that, there's nothing to this movie.  Awful characters doing awful things to each other.  I wouldn't recommend it in the slightest.  Not only is this an unnecessary remake, it is an exercise in futility.  Stay away from this.
Wow, you guys are hard to please! This movie kicks ass!

Holy shit! I thought this would be a Made-For-TV Canadian version, but I was so wrong! It does contain nearly word-for-word dialog at times but is a genuine remake that takes itself more seriously than the original and is by far more intense than the Eli Roth version. Recommended!
One of the worst movies I've ever seen.
Stupid dialogue, an inconsistent killer, bizarre characters, nonsensical scenes, and a decent soundtrack make this film your one-stop spot to shop for all your half-assed horror movie gimmicks.

By far one of the WORST remakes ever. I understand it’s not a reboot, it’s a remake. But fuck dude, you don’t film each scene the same exact scene the original was but with shitty acting and absolute no humor at all. I’m just... I hate this. Only reason it got the 1 star treatment and not a .5 is because some of that musical score was really hair raising.... until the characters started talking again
This movie was a joke

Not scary, just contains quite a bit of gore.  The acting isn't great which gets a bit irritating at times.  The story mainly sticks to the original script.  The effects are cool as the people really look like they're infected and very sick.

I didn't see the original film or the sequels, so I approached this remake with an open mind. This version of "Cabin Fever" is a cross between "Night of the Living Dead" and John Carpenter's  "The Thing."  There is a sense of doom, and paranoia grows among the principles as the film goes on. One scene in the film struck me as very funny. One of the principles exits a shed to find three "bad guys." The "hero" tries to shoot the three with his rifle but it doesn't fire. One of the bad guys says, "No, you got the safety on." The hero looks down, clicks the safety off, and then mows down all three badies. I mean, how stupid do you want to be?!
Just a rewrite of the original but not a bad film

I miss the comedy parts and it was over all useless. I mean the original came out in 2002, that really isn't a drastic age difference. I found my self getting really bored. Acting and graphics are the only thing that saved this movie from being a huge flop.
Boring and stupid. I love bad movies but this was not even entertaining as a bad flick. Skip.

Way worse than the original, which isn't that old anyway so it's weird this exists. And I like some of the actors cast but the FX, music and script are huge downgrades, and they messed up the iconic leg shaving scene from the original. Just watch the original, so much better.
No stars that's all I'm giving it

WHY!?!? I didn't even realize there was a remake.  I liked the original but there never ever ever ever was a need to remake/reboot it. I'd rather watch Slumber Party Massacre from the 80's than see this POS again.  Does anyone remember the Psycho remake.
Bad acting. Predictable plot.
The original is the worst piece of sh!t ever made, why would I want another one? Especially one that is literally 97% the exact same pos movie.

so so. concept of the story is nothing new, the story itself was taken from a previous version of the movie and the acting was kinda - boring...
it was good for killing some time, while waiting for a flight, but wouldnt recommend it to ppl who enjoy a proper horror movie...
Very bad cheesy offense to the genre.
A pointless and baffling production. Why this was made other than a misguided attempt to scrape up a few meager dollars is beyond my comprehension.

Much more blood and guts gore than the original, with a few effective jump scares, it does beg to ask the question why remake a film that isn't a classic in the first place? Some one should stop giving money to Eli Roth. Zero stars.

this movie all around sacked so much. the acting was horrible the scripts were horrible and the characters were horrible. Right off the start when the guy was bit by the kid and he says it's not the kids fault I was like wtf??? There's just so many parts that make all the people so dam stupid. Why would they remake this movie to be this stupid. please no one ever give this movie your time.
Good blood and gore but sluggish.
"they did not even try."
Same script, but stripped of all humor or edge. Lifeless and unnecessary.
This is the funniest horror film I think I have ever seen. Also way better than the original
Almost beyond description. Woeful.

Take the already not-the-great original movie, subtract 99% of the humour, gender-swap a single character and otherwise reel out a shot for shot remake. If that sounds worthwhile to you, I guess you could 2016's Cabin Fever a shot, but personally I'm still trying to figure out how (and more importantly why) this got made...

Great soundtrack though.
was close to the original
Jan 2017 - the good news is that it does end... eventually...

Not too bad compared to the original film, but as it's exactly the same thing it's hard to go completely wrong.  There is no point in this remake though, nothing is, nor needs updating... it must just be going for some kind of first remake of a 21st century movie record.
Cabin fever (remake.) What can I say. Um it was horrible . Nothing like the original , it was not intense, and the performance was terrible.A unnecessary remak.
bit of a pointless remake of an ok at best original. doesn't help that the characters are sadly lacking in character

I cannot understand why anyone would want to remake a movie, let alone one that wasn't very entertaining the first time around. Also, the original is only from 2002. It's the 2002 movie re-shot with a different cast. And thats about it.
Terrible. Why remake a movie to make it worse? ð???
I hadn't been aware that the powers that be intended to remake Eli Roth's 2002 gorefest, and now, having seen it, I'm unsure of why they did.
Someone needs to stop Eli Roth. He always fails.
this is the laziest horror ever made.
Not bad, just exactly the same movie as the original.

This film stands to prove that both the Horror genre and remakes no longer hold any integrity. If you're trying to clock in hours to fill for a horrorfest, chalk this one up with the rest of the B-movie lineup to make them look good.

It's actually well made, but it's just not good. The original Cabin Fever, from 2002, was a gritty, entertaining and disturbing horror movie, with a good campy tone and feeling to it. But this remake aims for big new quality, which isn't too bad either, but it's the fact that the characters do a catastrophic amount of stupid things, which just spoils the whole flick. The very first half is very good, but it then  just turns into an idiotic blood bath.

This is a strange one to judge.  Had I been completely unaware of the original Cabin Fever then I would have thought this was a top notch horror but I have seen the original which makes this a pretty pointless remake.  The eccentric characters and the stomach churning body horror are all still present, there have been a few character changes and it perhaps looks a little prettier but other than that it is pretty much a scene by scene remake of the original.  There is no new spin on the story, you could probably watch them both side by side and notice very little difference which begs the question, why?  Remakes are only good if the director has put a completely new spin on the story, shot it from a different perspective or made significant changes.  Copying the original scene by scene makes no sense, especially when the original was only released 15 years ago.  If you've seen the original it's not worth your time, if you're unaware of the original then it's worth a watch, although be warned, this one is missing the crazy hillbilly kung fu kid which was a highlight of the original!

Why remake a film only 14 years after it's release? Not THAT much worse than the original... but not very different at all. It's the same film with minimal changes to the script, different cast and different director... which is fine, but why? It's not a complete miss... it's just SLIGHTLY not as good as the first. That said... seems pointless.

i know the ending was cliche. however it is interesting movie as it is a horror/ gore/ Comedy movie. dont expect commercial art movie here. it is for comic horror fans.  just be relax and enjoy the film.
NO ONE ASKED FOR TEENAGERS GETTING DISEASED IN A CABIN, NO ONE, SO WHY DO WE FUCKING HAVE ONE.
Why? Why did this need to happen?

not as fun as Eli roths original film from 2003 ! that's for sure !! this one is more serious!  the original had a personality and it was entertaining!  this one felt like I wish had a copy of the original version so  I can take this remake out of my player for some entertainment!
Shot for shot remake of the original; this time lacking any soul whatsoever.

Going into this one, I was trying to figure out why they would remake a movie that is less than 15 years old, originally already an American movie and one of the better horror movies from the early 2000's.  My answer after having watched this one is that the studio and Eli Roth himself wanted to cash in on the success of the original film.

Here are my thoughts on the film.  What a waste of time with nothing really redeeming about it.  It was shot using the original script.  Almost a shot for shot remake.  This one had slight changes and different camera work.  This version took all of the funny spots from the original, I guess they were trying to make it more serious.  The acting wasn't good at all in this version.  The only thing that I think they pulled off right was the gore.  

With all of that said, stay away from this one.
Exception made on 2 or 3 shots, everything in this useless remake is pure garbage.

It is interesting that Roth in interviews beats himself up a little when he says his original script at 22 years old was shite. This remake is an interesting comparison f how the direction and actor can affect the content. Personally I think Roth is brilliant and this attempt shows how substance really shines through. The original Cabin Fever is one of my all time favorites in part due to its' campy humor. Yet done by a different director with the black comedy pushed aside it still holds up as a genuinely good flick. If you are a regular horror fan than tis one is decent. If you are looking for that other brand than stick with Roth's films. Thank you Eli.

Terrible, awful and hurt to watch! I can't believe they remade the same movie for a second time, also directed by the same director for a second time and turned into even more shit for a second time. This movie honestly makes the first cabin fever 2002 look like a descant movie.
not sure why this was remade. but the original one is better.
Pointless remake, but as a fan of good gore and practical effects I kinda enjoyed it...in a wrong way.

This is probably the worst yet in a long line of remakes.
The 2002 version seemed like a derivative cop out even back then, but It really makes you wonder how the makers thought they could get away with this. Takes the re-make idea to parody levels.
It would of been IDENTICAL to the original but the acting took a sharp dive and the new (Read: ripped off from Night of the Living Dead 1967) 30 second scene at the end.
Pitiful effort.

I really liked it just because I haven't watched the original in years! I really like the cast but I couldn't shake off how familiar the entire movie was. Like I said, it's been a while since I've seen the original so I'm not sure if it's 100% the same story, but it felt that way. Especially the "Plane" line...damn.

But to say this film wasn't entertaining is rediculous. Do I wish they have remade it in their own keeping some similarities, yes. But it is what it is. It's an enjoyable film.
The original is better.
While more consistant in style than the original, plays it too safe and looses that shlocky edge of the original to create a duller experience
I can not believe this is a film of 2016 .

Normally i would skip a remake but thought since Eli Roth was involved it might be worth  a redbox rental - nope. The original was no great film but it had passable acting and enough humor to make itself a cult favorite. This remake lacks all of those things and descends in to gore for the sake of knowing its a Roth's film sake. The same as the original,  minus all the good stuff about the original.
Don't waste your time or money. The original is so much better.  This is a cheap badly acted and directed almost copy of the original.
It was fun and gory. Graphic shit!
The original is looking pretty good right now.

I don't understand why this movie was made other than for a potential cash grab? This movie copied the last movie and didn't improve on a single thing. I was waiting for this movie to end before it was half way over. Everything about this movie was shitty except for the story itself which did not need to be retold. If you want to watch Cabin Fever, just watch the original. Don't waste time on this movie. I don't understand why Eli Roth allowed this to happen either other than potentially ego and money. He even gave it favorable reviews and said many positive things about this movie. This movie was shit. The original is a great horror film.

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse Burleson

"We can eat alone, we can sleep alone but we have to stick together". Huh? So quips the paperboard character of Paul from my latest review (he's played by Samuel Davis)

Anyway, the story of five campers subsiding to a flesh-eating virus, is redone in 2016's unrelieved Cabin Fever. If you've seen 2002's original, here's what's different: There's a dissimilar ending, there's an elaboration on the storyline, the Winston character is now a female, the music from The Shining is used in the opening credits, there is less utilization of a red-hued palate, and there are no bloodied flashbacks. Also, the murderous dog named Dr. Mambo is more frantically portrayed, there is virtually no 80's horror feel, and the characters are more sympathetic (I liked it better in the first flick when they were meaner to each other). Still, this comes off as an almost uniform, cash grab remake with director Travis Z (his real name is Travis Zariwny) not updating this thing with any real sense of style or substance (despite an ominous musical score). He decides to revel in paint-by-numbers filmmaking with his actors/actresses going through the motions as if they were robotic caricatures trying to be Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, and James DeBello (the troupers from the first movie).

In truth, Cabin Fever is a midsize, acting effort that's admirable despite a first hour that makes you want to turn the DVD player off (I was almost tempted to by sheer regularity). You pretty much know everything that comes around the corner. Heck, almost every frame is identical with previous helmer Eli Roth coming back to help out by co-writing the screenplay (did I mention that he's a producer as well).

See the new flick if you're part of a later generation (or if you've never viewed the first Cabin Fever) but know that most of it is a carbon copy of what was screened 14 years ago. That's too short of a wait to redo a film. You gotta let 2002's Cabin Fever breathe a little. Better than 1998's shot-by-shot re-imagining of Psycho but still not recommendable. Rating: 2 stars.

was okay. was weird in sense a remake thats actually a remake apart from more modern references but everything happened way did in first. remember really liking the original but not as much with this one. il need to watch original again as tastes change with time suppose. still gorey good bit action still has thay cringe factor.
This movie is a train wreck . Almost a comedy the acting is that bad. Come on Eli Roth you can make a better picture then this.

It has a horrible script and the acting is at par with a cheesy theater production with very little credibility. It gets boring within the first 5 minutes. I tried to stay for another 10 but it was just not optional without mind enhancing drugs to accept the acting. Terrible, just terrible.

Honestly, not the best reboot out there. The film was an exact script-for-script copycat of the original film. Why did this film even NEED to be remade? It didn't. At all. Why watch this when you could just watch the original? Only a few things were changed throughout this whole film. But positives? The gore was great, some of the acting wasn't terrible, and it was fun to see a female Winston! Also thought the picture of the girl and the dog was pretty badass when they were staring each other down. But could this film have done a lot better? Very much yes.

This is a remake from the earlier film, which makes no literal sense as to why they would redo it.
The characters are are entirely stupid and unbelievable, as their troupes are so bad that they seemed to be written by a fourth grader.
The plot is hamfisted and tries way to hard, albeit also very badly to hype up the tension of the encroaching sickness.
This movie is not even worth suffering though, Eli Wood dun goofed remaking this film.
A pointless remake that adds nothing to the original, which wasn't that great to begin with, and lacks the original's sense of humor.

Travis Z; sounds an awful lot like travesty. From a purely technical level, there's a lot that's actually semi-decent here. The photography is good, the acting is fine and it's made with competence. However as soon as you associate this with the original film it's a sin against nature. The film is 90% shot-for-shot, line-for-line the exact same film; offering only slight modern alterations to dialogue and revamped gorier death sequences. The film even goes as far to blindly duplicate Roth's original idiosyncratic side characters  and black comedy without any original flair of its own. The few times the film does start to follow its own path are jarring and very poorly done. The vitriol that should be spewed all over this movie has nothing to do with it being a remake of a fairly recent movie, it's because it's a lazy duplicate with no voice of its own and no rhyme or reason for even existing.

I don't remember disliking the first one this much. It was almost an exact imitation. I can't imagine why there was a need to remake this movie. It hasn't been that long since it came out and it is far from a classic! I read that there were better special effects, I must have missed that. It was a stupid movie all the way around.
I just realized it. Eli Roth sucks at horror movies. This is not scary, and NOT funny. Same shit, same wrapping. Foul taste.

There are times when remaking or reimagining of film is warranted. For stories that are so incredibly well constructed, epitomizing an aspect of the human condition, it is the right of every generation to reinterpret through the vantage point of their own experiences and social sensibilities. Many of the plays of William Shakespeare are perfect examples of this. No one would complain that place such as 'Romeo and Juliet' or 'Hamlet' has been reimagined more times that could easily be counted. Each one edited a different set of nuances, different perspectives that allow the generation to make the work their own expressing what is important to them. Then there are those movies the motivation behind the remake is exceptionally baffling. This is become a trend lately specifically in the horror genre with some of the major franchises have been taken up by a younger director hoping to reinvigorate a fan favorite. In recent years such horror classics as 'Nightmare on Elm Street', 'Halloween' and 'Friday the 13th' , have been reimagined with various levels of success. What is truly mystifying is when a relatively minor horror franchise is subjected to a modernizing revision. In the case of the movie considered here, 'Cabin Fever', the 2002 original was a barely passable beer and pizza flick. It was followed by two sequels was critical and fan appeal diminished with each release. Now will be six years later this film has been remade and after watching it I still have no reasonable explanation for how or why the studio backed this film. The only possible reason is that a 'Master of Horror 'with a proven track record decided to attach himself to the project, you are Eli Roth. He is one of the founding fathers of the torture porn subgenre. His film credits encompass such gruesome franchises as 'Hostel', and of course the 'Cabin Fever' series of movies. One of his most recent films, 'The Green Inferno', is a story of cannibalism greatly influenced by the notoriously deeply disturbed films, 'Cannibal Holocaust'. His recently branched out into television more traditional yet exceptionally intense shows as 'Hemlock Grove ' Fans of traditional horror movie should pray that he doesn't receive the financial means to subject us to another go at the 'Hostel' bloodbaths. If these films used animals as victims, then PETA would be utilizing it for a recruitment campaign.

As for the setup is concerned it is not fair to say is a direct report from the original movie. That would imply that the original movie had a modicum of originality. He had a group of five changeable characters of recent college graduates who are bored so they decide to head off to a remote cabin in the woods in order to drink, smoke pot and have sex. Need to travel so far away from home to engage in these activities is fairly believable with teenagers. For a group of college graduates one of them should have an apartment where least someplace closer than they can find some privacy. I was a teenager in Brooklyn New York all of these activities were readily performed without having so much to spend a single subway token to say nothing of having to travel into some deserted woodland. The archetypes used to define the five characters are direct from central casting including the requisite young woman capable of at least a modicum of reasonable thought, Marcy (Nadine Crocker), the contrasting girl was frequently found taking selfies, Karen (Gage Golightly), two main male leads, Marcy 's boyfriend Jeff (Matthew Daddario) and Paul (Samuel Davis) was trying to get out of the friend zone with Karen. Of course there is a need for a fifth wheel was supposed to provide some comic relief, Bert (Dustin Ingram). These are exactly the same names used in the previous incarnation of this film. At the very least he could've come up with different names or perhaps have will be more ethnically diverse. The biggest change in the film and the casting choice made for the local authority figure, Deputy Winston previously played by Giuseppe Andrews but now by recasting the role as a woman the character was taken up by Louise Linton.

You are so many places we a bit of imagination by the been able to creep into the script which was credited to Randy Pearlstein. He could've selected a different vector to initiate the spread of the infection rather than sticking with the dog and old man. Mr. Pearlstein does have some interesting credits however. He was the voice of several characters for the short-lived animated show on Comedy Central, 'The Americans' and appeared in several sketch comedy shows most notably single quote Chappelle's Show'. Previous to this film he was the screenwriter for both the original 'Cabin Fever' and 'Cabin Fever 2: Spring Fever'. Hopefully he doesn't happen to have an 'alternative 'screenplay for that sequel lying somewhere around his home. The request for all concerned that the infection stopped with this film. The director, Travis Zariwny, who chose to be credited here as Travis Z, has a resume that is predominantly short films. Unless all the circumstances it might be pertinent to state that currently has difficulty in maintaining a longer film that would be making the assumption that the longer movie contains a story that requires a it's running length to properly relate to the audience.

Just the only changes made 2002's attempt to the gross effects quotient. If you thoroughly pretty young woman in the bathtub shaving her legs was disgusting as the skin began to peel off, the effect of the virus in this film is far more devastating, particularly on the audience it has to watch it. I have come to the conclusion that the only one who did appreciate the special effects for the people who received special effects in order to come up with various delivery systems for several hundred gallons of fake blood that was required for this movie. There's one thing that can make seeds in a horror movie that rely solely on this very disturbing imagery it would be pulled morning the scenes fall beyond any necessity. You might think that the scenes just seem longer but if you take the time to compare the duration with the previous film see that they are indeed significantly longer. Come to think of it, it's pretty bad to start thinking about metric analysis during a horror film.

What is unusual is Mr. Roth's willingness to actively participate in this do-over. Since the screenwriter remained the same Roth received a secondary writing credit and was listed among the traditionally long list of executive producers. it is not unheard of for this credit to be used to credit people involved in some way with the project. A number of filmmakers have achieved a degree of name recognition. They are able to permit the use of their name in marketing as a form of branding. No matter how you try to put a positive spin on this flick anyone other than a diehard Eli Roth completest will choose to watch something else
A horror to avoid even for gore fans, this is the laziest remake ever and it is very stupid and quite frankly it should have been left alone.

There are pointless horror-film remakes, and then there is this. The original "Cabin Fever" is from 2002 and in no need of an update. This is almost an exact step-by-step remake with worse actors. Completely devoid of imagination or purpose. Why?

Cabin Fever is the reboot of the one done in 2002, I haven't seen the original one but this movie is horrible in terms of acting and dialog. I liked the music but it is not enough to save  it. Overall, a very poor horror predictable horror movie that doesn't have a single scary moment - Pass !

Confirming a fact that will surprise no one, the Cabin Fever remake sucks. It is worse than the original on every level. The acting is worse. The music is worse. The effects are worse. The comedy is worse. And possibly worst of all, it is 99% the same movie. Even down to the nougat line. The only real changes come toward the end of the movie and have no real consequence. If you are even slightly tempted to see the remake, DON'T! Just rewatch the original. It is in no way a great movie, but it is a better made, more fun movie.
Cabin Fever (2002) - 3.5 Stars
Cabin Fever (2016) - 0.5 Stars

The Cabin Fever remake is a huge improvement over Eli Roth's awful 2002 original in many ways and it is the best in the Cabin Fever franchise since the recently released prequel Cabin Fever Patient Zero. If you've watched the original Cabin Fever and you love Roth's original then this movie is not for you since its the same movie with the same plot and it is also using the exact same script with a series of changes in terms of dialogue, execution and tone. But if you watched the original and hate Eli Roth's original and is hoping for a new Cabin Fever movie either a remake, sequel or prequel whatever etc.... Then this movie is for you. The plot of this film is like the 2002 original which is about a group of College kids who are spending their vacation at a cabin in the woods, where soon after they kill an infected hermit. One of them starts to get the same disease as the Hermit and it is now up to them to try to find a way to save their sick friend or die trying. I really love this movie and I don't care if some people call this a shot for shot remake because it is using the exact same script with a series of changes in everything. But in my honest opinion I love this movie a lot more than Eli Roth's awful original because there are many reasons why I love this movie over the original. One of the reasons why I consider this to be a major improvement over the original Cabin Fever its because first of all I love how the tone was completely changed, right after I heard about a Cabin Fever remake in development I was really surprised with the idea despite that Cabin Fever Outbreak the second prequel to the original Cabin Fever was scrapped/canceled. I had so many hopes when I watched this film because I truly hate the original Cabin Fever(but at least the Unrated Director's Cut is more watchable than the theatrical version) the remake was able to really put adrenaline in the film itself and I love how the humor was removed in this movie and was replaced with a more serious and darker tone. Because in my honest opinion this is what the original Cabin Fever could have been in the first place and the humor in the awful original really ruined the overall look of the film which also is by the way the result of the bad acting by the way. Second the casting and character development are a miles better than in the awful original. Ok I admit that in the original the acting ranges from good to bad. In the original there were some outstanding performances throughout the first half. But the second half seriously destroyed the overall image of the film due to the mixing of humor with Horror and it was also responsible for the bad acting of the casts and the characters became unlikable throughout the film after the impressive first half. Here the acting is way better from start to finish and the casting is ten times better than in the original and I love the way Deputy Winston is a woman in this movie than in the original since Giuseppe Andrews was good in the original and was the comic relief in both the first movie and its first sequel. Here Deputy Winston is a woman who looks very attractive, sexy, smart and tough at the same time and she's more serious than comical like her male counterpart in the original which is in my opinion very good for a change and it works for a remake and I also love how the hillbillies in the original were replaced with Rednecks instead plus I love how the stupidest scene in the original which is the pancakes scene where Dennis bites one of the characters and do karate chops in front of the characters before biting was cut in this movie and the character of Dennis is creepier than in the original and last but not least. This movie is more intense and shocking than the original because the remake was able to seriously create more tension than the awful original. If you guys haven't noticed in the original the tension is gone in the next half of the film after the intense first half. Plus the remake's atmosphere is very mystic looking which I really enjoy in this movie. But what I like about the Cabin Fever remake is that this movie is packed with loads of scenes that are way more intense and creepier than in the original(The creepy sequence where Dennis wears a bunny mask while holding a teddy bear, the scene where you get to see Dr. Mambo bark and harass the group and the dog is way more terrifying in this movie than in the original and the sequence where Dennis bites Bert and gets chased by the rednecks plus the scene where Paul gets attacked by the Hermit was so intense) but the film's gore effects are the main highlights of this film and the kills are even bloodier, more disturbing and gorier than in the original and the death scenes are seriously super bloody and pure gross(Karen vomiting loads of blood, the infected Hermit showing his body rotting which is super gross, the infamous leg shaving sequence which was in the original and is more unflinching in this movie, the super bloody shovel shove to the mouth and several scenes where the characters start to see their skin fall apart as the disease consumes their body) plus I also love the soundtrack composed by Cabin Fever Patient Zero composer Kevin Riepl and the soundtrack is grittier and a bit more grounded and on the edge than his dark, powerful and synthetic score for Cabin Fever Patient Zero and it creates a very dark and gritty tone which is perfect for this film. Now the acting is seriously the best in this film. The performances of the casts in this film is seriously way better than in the awful original. Everyone in this movie did a very good job with their performances in this film and the personality and chemistry of each of the characters is way better than in the original at some point which is pretty true. Director Travis Zarwiny did an amazing job with his work on this movie than what Eli Roth did for his film back in 2002. In my honest opinion I would watch this again because this film is ten times way better than the awful original and Travis Zarwiny was able to put some impressive changes that really fits well for this film and the changes were completely necessary in my honest opinion and he seriously did a better job modifying Randy Pearlstein and Eli Roth's script with several changes. Overall this new Cabin Fever remake seriously surpassed the original in many ways and it is a miles better than the original. This movie is more entertaining and shocking and gorier than the awful Eli Roth original. This movie gets a 10/10.
But why? This is so boring, all of the characters range from annoying to completely forgettable. I really don't mind remakes that much anymore but I genuinely don't understand the point of this one.
The original is looking pretty good right now. This is yet another example of why remakes are completely pointless.
Pointless, shitty remake of an average gore flick.

Unnecessary, & ultimately underwhelming remake takes the "shot for shot recreation" approach on a film that came out only 13 years ago. Seems like an unlikely candidate for a remake at this point in time, but they did it, and now it exists, and suddenly the sequels to the original appear that much better to me.

I'll say the same thing about this movie that I said about the new Martyrs, a remake of a movie that I already didn't like.

Cabin Fever 2016. The storyline of this remake of the original, 2002 film, is almost identical just a lot less of everything that made the original horribly great. They really should have called it "Cabin Fever Lite". A few storylines seem like they are missing or only partially made the final cut. Deputy Winston's character is a women this time. She is the only real comic relief but there is just too little of her. All in all it was still a fun horror film and I recommend it.

 remake in the first place. Travis Z makes a film just as gory and twisted as Roth's original gore factory of goods. same movie same script but slightly darker and more gruesome if anything. All in all Cabin fever is not as bad as other horror remakes... AKA The fog 2005

Take away some bad acting, poor characterization and idiotic scenarios, the movie is a lot of fun. The score really meshed with the intensity of the movie to me. The last scene is actually quite clever, too. I had fun watching this movie, as a big fan of Eli Roth's original.
Same stupid movie as the original only with a better looking cast.

Even though it's a pointless remake, I have to admit this surprised me! Cabin Fever follows the original very closely with some scenes looking the exact same, as well as the dialogue. If I remember correctly, I read somewhere that the director of this remake used the script Eli Roth wrote for the original movie. Anyways, the movie follows five students going on a vacation in a cabin in the woods. Once there, a sick, bloody man comes to their cabin and asks for help. They all think he's infected and want nothing to do with him. So they burn him. And before you know it, they're getting infected one by one and trying to find out what's causing it and how to stop it. It's not a really great or mind-blowing story, but it's entertaining and interesting. As I said, the movie is the same as the original, so watching this movie is quite pointless if you've seen the original, but I will say that the gore and violence looks better in this movie. There's also more of it. It's still not a scary movie, though. The acting is okay. The characters are okay, they all serve their purpose in the movie, but as expected they're aren't really developed that much for you to care for them. The direction, I thought, was great! The locations looked really cool and there were some really nice shots in this movie. The soundtrack is good, as well. Though I did notice that at a few times the soundtrack would be so loud, you could barely hear the characters talk. The ending is great. The entire last half an hour is great, to be honest. Since I really like the original, I can't say I don't really like this because it's more or less the same movie. Same story. All in all, albeit pointless, Cabin Fever does offer some awesome gore moments with a good soundtrack and great direction. I would recommend this movie to the fans of the original, to those who haven't seen the original, but are interested in this movie, go watch the original first.
Not sure if better or worse than the 2002 original
OMG what a pointless remake!
Eli Roth's 2016 remake of Cabin Fever undoubted brings nothing new---other than a higher gore factor---which is nowhere nearly enough to overshadow the fact that it is a recycled, same-scripted mess.
Unfunny, unscary, unnecessary. This might win the award for worst acting ever in a horror movie, and that's saying something.
